So What‚Äôs It About?
In a corporate-dominated space-faring future, planetary missions must be approved and supplied by the Company. For their own safety, exploratory teams are accompanied by Company-supplied security androids. But in a society where contracts are awarded to the lowest bidder, safety isn‚Äôt a primary concern.

On a distant planet, a team of scientists is conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‚Äòdroid--a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module and refers to itself (though never out loud) as ‚ÄúMurderbot.‚Äù Scornful of humans, Murderbot wants is to be left alone long enough to figure out who it is, but when a neighboring mission goes dark, it's up to the scientists and Murderbot to get to the truth.

What I Thought

I‚Äôve heard people sing praise to Murderbot for years now, and I‚Äôm kind of embarrassed that it took me so long to get on the bandwagon. But I read All Systems Red! Finally! And now I‚Äôm bandwaggoned!

This novella is fast-paced, inventive, and clever all throughout. Murderbot‚Äôs head is a fascinating one to be in, both because of how it sees the world and functions through technology and because of its complete awkwardness and mortification around humans. I think this is really well done given the way it has existed with and been treated by humans before. You might expect Murderbot to immediately embrace kind treatment instead of what it usually receives, but it responds with panic instead, which feels like such smart writing and characterization.

Despite its alleged apathy towards humankind, Murderbot is still really fond of its humans and does its very best to take care of them as best it knows how. I also really loved seeing how humans reacted to it. Some trusted it while others didn‚Äôt; some saw it as an equal person while others didn‚Äôt; some asked disconcerting questions about whether it hates or blames humans.

My only real complaint is that I think Wells missed an incredible opportunity by choosing not to incorporate the media Murderbot loves more. We‚Äôre always hearing about how it goes off to watch its shows, but I wish we had heard more about the actual content of those shows and what Murderbot thinks of them. There‚Äôs an incredible moment where someone in the team reveals that Murderbot has been watching human media and another person says something about one of the characters on the soap opera it‚Äôs watching being guilty of a salacious act that they were accused of. To this (completely distracted from the confrontation it‚Äôs in the middle of) Murderbot heatedly responds ‚ÄúNo, she fucking didn‚Äôt.‚Äù I LOVED this moment. It‚Äôs hilarious, of course, but it‚Äôs also just such a good moment of characterization - a show of rare, relatable emotion that demonstrates how invested Murderbot is in its media. I could see this getting overdone, of course, but I think even a few more moments like that could have added so much. That being said, this was an incredible amount of fun and I can‚Äôt wait to read more!

What was I supposed to do, kill all human because the ones in charge of constructs in the company were callous? Granted, I liked the imaginary people on the entertainment feed way more than I liked real ones, but you can‚Äôt have one without the other.

Should I be worried? I spent the last three months endlessly watching entertaining feeds and/or raging at stupid people in the news. I might be turning into a murderbot, or maybe I am simply programmed to think I am human, until my secret corporate masters will push the button to activate me. You‚Äôd better watch out, there will be mayhem once I go out of quarantine!

All System Red is the first novella in a new science-fiction project that is tightly plotted, fast-paced and funny. A first person narration from a serial killer perspective, our host is a construct of organic and electronic elements, a Security bot assigned to a geological survey team on a recently discovered exoplanet.

We all know, thanks to Isaac Asimov, that robots and artificial intelligence in general are subjected to the Laws of Robotics, the prime directive of which says that they should not harm their human masters. But an artificial intelligence is by definition a software capable of learning, and the one that calls itself Murderbot has taught itself some high level hacker code, enough to disable the governor that enforces the Law of Robotics. In its own defense, the Murderbot is annoyed when put to work for the survey team, preferring instead to watch endless re-runs of popular soap operas in space. Because, you know, anything is better than going back to work!

Joking aside, the novella does a great job at setting up the debate of how we define humanity and how we take responsibility for our own actions.
I will probably read the next three episodes in the following days, curious to see how free will can deal with deeply entrenched paranoia against armed and dangerous intelligent entities who take a critical view of our society.

‚ÄòAll Systems Red‚Äô by Martha Wells is the first of what will be called the Murderbot Diaries. The narrator is a snarky robot who speaks like a witty teenager. Xe (it does not have a sex, so using s/he pronouns are erroneous, so, I will use Xe) is a security bot or SecUnit. Xe works for a commercial company responsible for setting up transportation, habitat construction and security for other private for-profit companies or humanitarian or scientific non-profits who wish to explore other planets occupied by non-sentient life forms or simply planetary objects which have important minerals which can be monetized.

Xe calls itself Murderbot because its programming involves killing anything which threatens the people who have contracted with the Company for exploration services. However, the Company and everybody else does not know Murderbot hacked its own governor module after a previous protection assignment went wrong. Xe has been autonomous ever since.

As the novella opens, Xe is protecting a non-profit group of scientists exploring a planet full of non-sentient life. Xe thinks they seem nice, but humans do not really interest Xe beyond paying attention if they ask it. Mostly Xe watches downloads of soap operas while scanning the area for trouble periodically.

Xe‚Äôs humans are busy exploring a crater when stuff begins to happen which require Xe's services - very bad, life-threatening stuff, the kind of trouble which looks like someone or something is trying to kill all of the scientists! The scientists are scared and so is Xe! What is going on? It is possible from clues that Murderbot's owners, the Company, could be part of whatever is happening. Something issued a command to Xe, trying to take control. No one knows Xe hacked the governor module, so Xe is on its own. As far as Xe is concerned, no one is going to harm the human scientists! Xe sort of likes them. So do I, gentle reader.

I highly recommend this novella. It is a really fun adventure, well written, and very entertaining. It also is sneakily exploring situations in which people and sentient, but enslaved, robots might find themselves interacting.

Xe felt female to me, but maybe you will see Xe differently. Let me know.

Having less time for leisure reading nowadays novellas are just the thing to avoid taking too long to read just one book. So I found All Systems Red, a novella that won both the Hugo and Nebula awards, this seemed a just the thing. ‚Ä¶ But is it? Yeah, it is.

The novella‚Äôs title intrigued me, in a clickbaity kind of way. As it turned out the ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù part of the title is just about the only thing I do not like about this (e)book. I feel that it is not representative of what the book is about, what the Murderbot does throughout the entire narrative is the exact opposite of murdering people. Having said that there was some extensive murdering in his past, vaguely referred to but not depicted. I suspect subsequent volumes of this Murderbot Diaries series will contain more suitably mudery scenes (probably in flashback).

All Systems Red is the first volume of an ongoing series called The Murderbot Diaries which spans several novellas, a short story and a full length novel in the works. This first volume introduces the unnamed protagonist and first-person narrator who called himself ‚ÄúThe Murderbot‚Äù inside his mind. To the humans, he is the ‚ÄúSecUnit‚Äù, a cyborg ‚Äúconstruct‚Äù in charge of security and safety of the humans in the survey team he is assigned to protect. The novella is set on an alien planet where a scientific expedition is surveying the planet‚Äôs properties and life forms. When the survey team loses contact with another team they investigate and find that this entire other team has been murdered. It soon becomes apparent that the members of the survey team in the SecUnit‚Äôs care are also in mortal danger, and they must be kept alive at all costs.

On the surface All Systems Red is just a sci-fi thriller, with some elements of a murder mystery, espionage, and conspiracy. Digging a little deeper there is some depth underneath the casual colloquial prose style. Throughout the narrative the SecUnit finds human behavior puzzling and human society awkward and uncomfortable. However, he is very dedicated to his assignment of protecting the people under his charge even to the extent of self-sacrifice if necessary. The SecUnit has a hacked ‚Äúgovernor module‚Äù which enables him to override or ignore commands that he would normally be compelled to follow. This freedom not enjoyed by other constructs also allows for independent thinking which leads to a sort of humanizing ‚ÄúPinocchio‚Äù effect. The best sci-fi often holds up a mirror to our reality and makes us look at ourselves from a different, even-nonhuman, perspective and this is what All Systems Red does so well. The only thing that holds it back from five-stardom is that I do not find the human characters to be as well developed as the cyborg, they all seem to blend into each other and are a little lacking in individuality. Perhaps the author, Martha Wells, became so engrossed in breathing life into the SecUnit character that she accidentally overlooked the people in the survey team. In any case, this is a small gripe and should not dissuade anyone from reading this great little novella.

Murderbot. An ominous name for an Artificial Intelligence (AI) that helps humans out in the future. Martha Wells has given us the first installation (a short novel) of Murderbot in All Systems Red. This is a spunky, fun and adventurous little book. It has lots of action and diverse personalities; not the least of which is Murderbot.

Robots and Gender
I'm not sure why, and have been thinking about it for days, but I see Murderbot as a woman. This may be because I am a woman and so identify with the AI directly. It maybe that my bisexual mind just likes boobs; or it may be that I want strong robot AI's to be female because women deserve to be lethal as well. I really don't know. All I know is Murderbot was a woman for me from the first page and they have continued to be a woman in my head. Even though Wells uses they, them pronouns for Murderbot. I'm sure there is an interesting sociological or gender studies paper to be written about what gender readers see Murderbot as. Maybe the beautiful of Murderbot is that you can give them the traits you want to be gender neutral or not.

Action Packed
All Systems Red is full of adventurous action. From the opening page where we learn of the mining expedition Murderbot is on to the closing chapter in which a most unusual event occurs; All Systems Red delivers a quick read if nothing else. I really enjoyed the action. Although at times I did feel like the plot was a little complex (or maybe how the companies were structured was the problem) to follow. But it didn't really matter at the end of the day because the only important thing is Murderbot.

Overall - Ready for the Next One!
I already have the second book 'Artificial Condition' on the go. At less than 200 pages these short novels are fun, fast and helping me reach my (very behind) 2018 reading goal. Because Wells has kept all of the Murderbot stories short it doesn't hurt to try it out and see for yourself if it's your thing. I like them and could certainly see myself revisiting them for a reread break at times because they are quick and easy.

Murderbot is a security android, tasked with keeping an exploratory team safe. The humans think Murderbot is just a mindless robot like the rest of the security androids. They couldn‚Äôt be more wrong.


Plot-wise, it‚Äôs quite straight forward but solid and intensely gripping. It reminds me a bit of the Riddick movie Pitch Black for all the right reasons. With a group of humans being stalked and a not entirely human killer protecting them from harm. Especially with the way some humans look at the one person who can protect them, eyes full of doubt and suspicion. Afraid of the unknown basically. Though the book is much more character-driven rather than action-packed. And the plot is actually elevated by Murderbot wanting to protect its humans, while also trying to hide the fact that it broke free from its corporate limitations.


The biggest attraction of this story is without a shred of a doubt the protagonist. The character of Murderbot is just an absolute homerun and it‚Äôs so easy to fall in love with this android. Murderbot might be an android and it‚Äôs definitely not entirely human in more ways than one, but it is also very relatable. Murderbot is pretty much an introverted teenager. It appears to be wasting time in its formative years by watching tons of mindless entertainment. But it‚Äôs actually trying to figure out who or what it wants to be in life. It does so by secluding itself. So it can experiment with what it‚Äôs like to be its own boss, instead of always just blindly following the orders it has been given.


The ending doesn‚Äôt give us readers the most obvious satisfying climax to the story. But maybe that‚Äôs a good thing. And in its defense, it‚Äôs without a doubt a solid ending and it fits perfectly with Murderbot‚Äôs character arc.

As a premise I find it quite interesting and I was looking for something funny and quirky as such a character can find itself in all kinds of comedic situations and I thought it had potential to be really enjoyable and different.

All that character I was waiting for was completely missing from the entire work and the original selling point of the novel turned out to be represented by the main character uttering "I want to watch TV" or some equivalent every 10 pages or so. Given my penchant for reading large and/or heady books, this one was pretty much a "blink and you'll miss it" deviation for me. It was also our book club pick following the behemoth that was Brandon Sanderson's The Way of Kings, and we chose it because it was an easy read, which we felt was necessary after wading through the 1000+ pages of TWoK.

So what did I think of All Systems Red? Well, it was...good. That's about the best I can come up with at the moment. I loved the idea of a rogue Security bot that hacked its own governor, stopped caring about the corporate mission, and decided to basically be a TV junkie. And the fact that it refers to itself as Murderbot was just priceless. But outside of those concepts, the story just didn't really move me like I hoped it would.

Part if this is, I'm sure, due to the brevity of the tale. There's not a lot of room for character arcs or deep plotting in a story this short. And I get it...it's not supposed to be a monster story. This is popcorn entertainment, and it achieves that goal rather well. But, that being said, I still was left feeling a little cold after reading All Systems Red. Nobody really gets any backstory or context, the people in the tale are essentially just random people who are assigned various archetypes and behaviors to stand out. I never got much of a visual of any of them. As for Murderbot, while admired the snarky way in which it narrated its tale, I still wanted to know more about it, and this never really came to pass.

Another thing that took away from my enjoyment is the way in which the narrative unfolds. I've read several books where the storytelling was...incidental at best. But All Systems Red takes the cake. Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, was just kind of half-explained or defined. From the action to the locations to the characters themselves, nothing is written in much detail. In fact, the action scenes were comprised mostly of passages that read something like "I ran at it while shooting my projectile weapon. It was shooting at me at the same time. I got hit a few times, but I managed to find a vital area on my opponent and take it down." And...that's it. The problem with writing like this is it robs the story of any sense of drama or suspense. It's all so...casual. And that casual writing makes the narrative casual as well, which doesn't help to engage the reader as much.

Because this is a short novella, we jump from sequence to sequence pretty quickly, but even on things that I felt should have been given more weight, Martha Wells just kinda glosses over them. Not having read any of her other works, I can't say if this is just how she writes, or if she had to constrain herself to keep the story short & sweet. Again, I wanted more.

But it's not all bad! Murderbot is a fun narrator, and carries the first person POV tale quite well. I enjoyed the snark, the sarcasm, and the flippancy in which it viewed most situations it found itself in. I loved how anti-social Murderbot was, and how it really just wanted to be left alone to watch its video entertainment...aka soap operas.

The overall concept is also rather cool, but I feel that this could have been far more impactful as either a full-length novel or a larger novella. I wanted more heft with my tale, and I never received that. But I can see the potential here, and given that this is the first in a series of books, I think Martha Wells can certainly take this character in interesting directions. The ending of this one opens up all sorts of possibilities, and I'd like to see what is next for Murderbot.

Martha Wells‚Äô novella about a disaffected robot struggling with identity issues is like a set of Russian nesting dolls: there are stories within stories. It's an impressive accomplishment and Wells says more in 144 pages than most authors do in their 1,000-page trilogies.

The main story arc is a high-octane adventure about a sentient robot assigned to protect a group of scientists on their survey of a planet from sabotage, man-eating wildlife, and armed invaders from another company determined to take control of the planet at any cost. I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.

Murderbot is the AI version of the sensitive loner in high school. The edgy introvert who would rather read Jack Kerouac than attend social events. Lightning fast and armed with energy cannons, Murderbot is a fighting machine that doesn‚Äôt want to fight. It‚Äôs a reluctant hero who would rather be left alone to watch media, but it feels a responsibility to get the hapless humans to safety. Like so many readers, I related to Murderbot from page one and loved its sarcastic sense of humor. Despite its preference for mainlining galactic soap operas, there are plenty of gun fights and last-minute rescues for readers who want a fun adventure story.

I knew I could kill everyone on the hopper, even with a blown hip joint and one working arm. So I grabbed the hand weapon on the seat, turned it toward my chest, and pulled the trigger.

The second story arc is about free will, personhood, and the future of AI. SecUnits like Murderbot are leased out by their corporate owners to protect human clients; they are considered property rather than people. While robots can be citizens in some territories outside corporate space, they are second-class citizens at best who are required to have human guardians. Sentience and the desire for self-determination are not sufficient for bots to be free or equal to humans. The author contrasts Murderbot‚Äôs experience with Gurathin, a human cyborg on the survey team. While both Murderbot and Gurathin are part organic and part machine, Gurathin is a citizen with all the attendant rights, simply because he was born human. Murderbot was built in a lab, so it despite its intelligence, cloned human tissue, and the ability to have feelings, it is considered a machine no different than a PC. Murderbot is trying to decide who it wants to be and how it wants to live in a society that doesn't allow it to make either of those decisions.

Basically, you have unchecked capitalism vs. democratic socialism as co-existing philosophies in space, although it's unclear how that happened.
